title: Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off
text:
Ross County Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off Premiership clashes against Hearts and Aberdeen have the fired-up Staggies in upbeat mood after fixtures against Hibs and Rangers were postponed.
By Paul Chalk December 28 2023, 10.30pm Share Derek Adams is upbeat despite latest Ross County call-off Share via Facebook Twitter Whatsapp Messenger Linkedin Email Post link https://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/sport/football/ross-county/6309617/derek-adams-is-upbeat-despite-latest-ross-county-call-off/ Copy Link Ross County manager Derek Adams. Image: SNS Group
Ross County boss Derek Adams is confident a second successive call-off won‚Äôt affect his players as they seek to defeat Hearts at Tynecastle this weekend.
Last Saturday‚Äôs home Premiership match against Hibs was postponed due to a waterlogged pitch.
Then, on Wednesday, with County stuck on the snowbound A9, the SPFL, aided by Police Scotland‚Äôs advice, opted to postpone their match against Rangers at Ibrox.
It means the Staggies have not played since their last-gasp 1-0 home defeat to Dundee on December 16.
Now they prepare to face in-form Hearts at Tynecastle, fresh from the Jambos‚Äô dramatic 1-0 derby win at Hibs, thanks to a winner from Lawrence Shankland.
The impact of Storm Gerrit on Wednesday caused major travel trouble throughout part of Scotland, with Aberdeen v Motherwell also called off.
The A9 was shut both ways due to heavy snowfall at the Drumochter and Dalwhinnie sections, with flooding soon after affecting the Ballinluig and Dunkeld areas.
Steven Ferguson says A9 closure made it impossible for Ross County to continue journey for Rangers match
Although Rangers and County wanted the game on, there was an agreement that safety came first for fans of both sides travelling as well as the visitors who were facing a losing battle to reach Glasgow.
Extra training time was real positive Adams looked at the positive side of the situation as he gained extra training time on Thursday.
He said: ‚ÄúIt was the correct decision (to postpone the match).
‚ÄúThe league had to make that decision on Wednesday afternoon, because as we all know the A9 was closed for much of the day and it was going to be impossible not just for us to get to the game, but for supporters from both sides to get to the game.
‚ÄúIt was the correct decision. We‚Äôre all disappointed the game was off, but there was no other decision the league could have made.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just something that you have to deal with ‚Äì it‚Äôs not too big of a problem.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been able to train in Dingwall, but from our point of view we‚Äôve missed two games against Hibernian and Rangers.
‚ÄúWhat it has done is allow us some training time.‚Äù
Players will be ready for hectic run With just 17 league matches played, only Aberdeen with 16, have played fewer fixtures than County, with games stacking up for after the winter break which follows this Tuesday‚Äôs clash between the north rivals in Dingwall.
Adams says his players will relish rather than dread the packed schedule following their Scottish Cup tie against Partick Thistle on January 20.
He said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre obviously going to go back into a period at the end of January and February where we‚Äôre playing on Saturdays and Tuesdays for a bit.
‚ÄúThat will be nice, because the players probably enjoy that more than training.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôll get a period of rest from games for two and a half weeks, but we‚Äôll be training hard in that period too.‚Äù

County are keen to test hosts Hearts Shankland is hogging the headlines due to his goal exploits, but Hearts also have three clean sheets in a row as they sit third in the top-flight.
Adams, however, backs County to ask questions of Steven Naismith‚Äôs side in the capital.
He said: ‚ÄúWe have to go there and create opportunities, take the ball and get into that final third.
‚ÄúWe obviously have to deal with the threat of not only Lawrence Shankland, but the other players who have done well for them this season.
‚ÄúThey are third in the league for a reason, and they have done well in the league, and in Europe, over a number of seasons.‚Äù
Seven-point haul so far for Adams Since Adams replaced Malky Mackay as the manager of County for his third spell in charge, they have taken seven points out of 15.
A 0-0 draw against Kilmarnock preceded 1-0 and 3-0 wins over St Mirren and Motherwell .
St Mirren‚Äôs 2-0 win against County in Paisley was Adams‚Äô first defeat since the start of his third spell in charge then the sore 1-0 loss to Dundee kept the Dingwall team on 17 points.
